DataElement.preferredName: Personal Medical History Height at Time of Procedure Unit of Measure
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The unit of measure for the height of an individual at the time of a procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Personal Medical History Height at Time of Procedure
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies._The height of an individual at the time of a procedure.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

Property.preferredDefinition: The height of an individual at the time of a procedure.

Concepts.definition: The height of an individual at the time of a procedure.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: general description of an individual's physical appearance and vital status.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension._A named quantity in terms of which other quantities are measured or specified, used as a standard measurement of like kinds.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.

Concepts.definition: A basic unit of length in the former CGS version of metric system, equal to one hundredth of a meter or approximately 0.393 700 787 inch.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A traditional unit of length equal to 1/12 of a foot or 2.54 centimeters.

Concepts.definition: A traditional unit of length equal to 1/12 of a foot or 2.54 centimeters.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
